segments.text: It was something that was always in the background, but it never really bothered me very much.
Now, some people have said that there's sort of a ring-knockers club with West Pointers, and as far as promotions are concerned, they always look for their own.
What do you think about that?
Is there sort of a club?
Do you move up the ladder of success faster if you're a West Pointer, or doesn't it make any difference?
I think overall that's true.
I really do.
I hate to say it.
But I think overall, in a general statement, I believe that's correct.
Specifically, and on a case-by-case basis, why there's plenty of good evidence that says that that's not the case.
But I think when you look at it as a whole, I believe it would be.
It's probably...

working there was probably a period right after World War II and for many years thereafter when we had so many integrated officers into the regular army such as myself that were given the opportunity to integrate into the regular army that there was a preponderance then of officers both senior and junior
in the regular establishment who were not West Pointers.
We may be gradually working to the point now where that percentage is not as big as it was right after World War II
When you were in the Corps of Cadets, did you hold a position of leadership?
No, no I was not.
I sure wasn't.
Why do you think that was?
Later you did so well in the military.
I don't really know.
I guess because maybe I missed a lot by
being in the athletics in the football squad every fall.
And I was not a Ross volunteer and well I just don't really know and it never never really bothered me particularly.
I felt I didn't feel any disappointment about it.
Did you feel that the Corps had any impact on you for later becoming a general officer?
No, I don't think so, no.
So you don't think it affected you one way or the other as far as becoming a leader?
No, I don't think so.
Sure don't.
What about the idea that some journalists state that there's a military mentality
that there's a way that the military does something and then there's a way that businessmen do things.
Do you believe in the military mentality?
No, I don't.
I think that's a fallacy and that's just a snap phrase or a catchphrase that somebody has invented, much like this concept that was
that was attributed to General Eisenhower of the military industrial complex.
He did make a statement about that in a speech, but there's really no such thing as a military industrial complex.
I made several speeches on that subject during my military career and

I think General Eisenhower, I've read some things about his speech where he mentioned that he didn't write that speech, it was written for him, and people say that he never read it prior to delivering it, or he never would have mentioned the phrase military.
back there hoovering over the country, i.e.
the military industrial complex that dictates what weapon systems we'll buy and how many and how much and so forth.
And I think that's just a bunch of crap, really.
I don't put any belief in it at all, because if there was, I was certainly a part of it.
of being a part of it.

Because in my last command at the Defense Personnel Support Center, which was a joint staff organization that was staffed, I had Army, Air Force, Navy, and Marine Corps officers, and we had worldwide responsibility for all of the clothing, all of
the medical and dental for all the armed forces.
And I had it during the Vietnam period and the Vietnam build-up period and in fiscal year 66 my total budget was 3.2 billion in that one command.
And the subsistence part of it, the food part of it,
was 1.3 billion, and the clothing was about 1.1.

And if there ever was an opportunity for the military industrial complex, the Burlington Mills, the J.P. Stevens, the big weaving companies, and Hart, Schaffner, and Marks, the big fabricating companies, to have functioned, I certainly would have been knowledgeable of it and had a part of it.
And just the opposite was the case because during that time the whole country was in the throes of a very, very good business boom.
Business was booming and civilian business was booming and Johnson was trying to fight the war and to have guns and butter too.
And we couldn't get covered.
We'd go out, our procurement officers would go out with a procurement to buy clothing, buy Air Force clothing or Army clothing, and nobody would bid on it.
Nobody would bid on it.
So what did we have to do?
Finally, after talking to the DOD and everybody, they said, look, we're probably going to have to implement
the War Powers Act of directed orders, directed procurement.

And during World War II, Congress passed a law which said that the military, in wartime necessity, could place orders directly upon American industry for them to produce military supplies and equipment for the war effort
and that the Department of Commerce would be the government agency to adjudicate any claims or disputes arising between the military and industry, and that the prices that we would
would pay for these directed orders and supplies would be that which was adjudicated to be fair market value by the Department of Commerce and so on and so forth.
And there was regulations set forth about if you place an order on a company, they had 30 days to appeal and so forth.
So they told me one day, they said, look, I think we're going to have to use this wartime act.
They said, we've never used it before.
And I think it was used one time in World War II, but everybody in World War II was patriotic and everybody wanted to do their share.
So I got the go-ahead from the DOD one Friday afternoon.
So I called all our clothing and equipment people in and procurement people.
I said, look, we've got three or four million
Air Force and Army uniforms and Marine and everything and Navy to buy here and we haven't got coverage on.
I said let's figure out and we know who the potential suppliers are.
Let's parcel it out and prepare the telegrams for my signature and we'll start sending them out tonight.
And by Monday morning, they worked all weekend and we sent out, oh, about 190 to 200 telegrams to industry.
Said, we are hereby, under the War Powers Act of 1941, you are hereby directed to produce 250,000 of this and 300,000 of that.
Well, you can imagine the hue and cry that resulted on Monday and Tuesday.
why the goddamn people in industry are flying in and driving in and they're congressmen and everything and we're just saying we're sorry there's a war going on now you do it.
You have 30 days to appeal if you don't want to do it and the Department of Commerce will adjudicate it and only two or three of them appealed it.
Every goddamn one of them took it and we used it
We used it hundreds of times during Vietnam.
Yeah.
We directed them to do it.
Just sent them a damn telegram.
You are hereby directed to produce this.
And we told them how much we were paying for it and everything.
And it was a fair market.
They all made money.
They all made money by it, but they just didn't want to interrupt their civilian business.
They said, well, we'll lose all our civilian business.
I said, well, that's fine.
What are the guys going to Vietnam going to wear?
What are they going to wear?
And what are we going to do for this and for that?
So we didn't have any problem.
But if there was a military-industrial complex, that would certainly have been a good place for it to come forth.
There wasn't any.
So I think- So you think the whole idea of the military industrial complex and military mentality are both a myth?
They're a myth.
They certainly are.
I think they're a myth.
Okay.
Now let's start talking about when you graduated.
Did you have firm plans?
Did you get a job?
Did you interview for jobs or did you want to go into the military?
After I didn't make the Army Air Corps.
I then went to Root.
I was already, I already knew how to fly.
And I was, I wanted to go to work for a major oil company and I did.
I had one interview and got a job and reported out to- This is 1934.
This is 1934.
I reported in September 1934 to the Gulf after division off
by car down to Crane, 35 miles south of Odessa.
Not even a railroad in Crane County.
And I went to work down there in a connection gang.
And I'm making 70 cents an hour.
Is that what you were making?
Yeah, 70 cents an hour.
Did any of your other colleagues get jobs?
Yes.
Or were there very few jobs?
No, I think all of, best of my knowledge, all of the
All of the P.E.
guys got jobs.
Most of them went to work for Humble, which is now Exxon.
I had sort of wanted to go to work for Humble, and I asked for an interview.
One of our assistant professors was a former Humble guy, the little shrimp, and he didn't like me for some reason or another.
But I didn't get the invitation to come to Houston for an interview and I think it was because of him.
But anyway, I was happy to work with Gov.
They had a division office here in Fort Worth and I had met through my father one of the guys there, one of the superintendents there.
And Gov was strong in West Texas and I started to lean to West Texas.
So I was just thrilled to death to go to work for golf.
And there were six of us that reported out there, six young college graduates.
There was...
Were you all A&M?
No, no, I was the only A&M.
Oh, okay, that's what I figured.
There was one from the Rolla School of Mines that later, that lived with me out there.
We lived in bunk houses.
In other words, Missouri.
Yeah, in Missouri, Rolla, Missouri.
And another one from the University of Pittsburgh.
His family was friends of the Mellons, the principal owners of Goff.
Oh, there was another Aggie, yeah.
Del Brockett, E.D.
Brockett.
And I'll tell you a little story about Del.
And you really ought to interview Del Brockett.
He never became a flag officer, but he was a colonel.
And a combat officer.
How do you spell his name?
Brockett.
E-D is initials.
B-R-O-C-K-E-T-T.
If you interview anybody, you ought to interview him.
Because Adele Brockett was a P.E.
And he was in that group.
And we both worked in the same connection gang.
And I tell this story.
Adele probably...
would be mad as hell, me tellin', he probably wouldn't subscribe to it.

But I, whenever we were doin' a real tough job, like layin' four-inch pipe and buckin' it with chain tongs and pipe tongs, well, the gang foreman would, you know, say, get the tongs and get that, and Del would always get the lazy board or the dope bucket, some easy job, see?

and whenever we were working in a cellar of a well or something, I was always among the first guys to get down in the muck and get dirty and Del would do his share, but his would be a cleaner job, see.
Well, Del Brockett later became the chairman of the board of Gulf Oil.
That's why you ought to interview him.
E.D.
Brockett, he's a distinguished alumni, has given
fifty or sixty thousand dollars, and E.D.
Brockett, Del Brockett, he lives now in Baton Rouge.
A hell of a nice guy.
I really think a lot of him.
But he was, he became the chairman of the board of Gulf Oil.
And I think his salary, according to poop I used to read in annual reports and everything,
I think his remuneration his last year was about $300,000 salary and another two or three hundred in bonuses and incentives and so forth.
So Dell is a wealthy man.
I don't know how many thousands of shares of Gulf stock he has now.
Probably has a retirement of 150 or 200,000 a year.
Is he retired now?
Yeah, he's retired now.
So, you really ought to interview Dale Brockett.
God almighty, he had a brilliant combat record in the South Pacific.
He commanded a combat engineer battalion, I think later a regiment.
He was a full colonel and I'm sure you could get a lot of good comments and narrative from him about
what it takes and how he approached what he did to become the titular head of about the fifth or sixth largest oil company in the world.
Anyway, I was happy to go down there to Crane and I really enjoyed every minute of it there.
We worked in this connection gang just like commonly
one day they, Adele was assigned to the engineering department and they told me to report to the drilling department.
I worked out on the deep test.
They had a rotary rig running and drilling a deep well, which we later got the world's record at that time.
We drilled to 12,786
Dell was in the engineering department taking bottom hole pressures and things like that.
But this group of six all went on and worked their whole careers with Gulf except me.
I worked about three years there and

One day, one of the superintendents of Gulf that I had become acquainted with, and he liked me, he said, you know, he said, I had a call here the other day from a supply house that we do a lot of business with, wanting to know if we had an engineer that would like to work for them.
And he said, it's a pretty good thing, monetarily, he said,
Anybody that would probably make more money quicker working for a supply house as a sales engineer than they would working for Gulf and coming up through the ladder through the years.
He says, would you be interested?
And I said, well, I might be, yeah.
So two, three days after that, they called me.
And wanted to know if I could come down to Beaumont for an interview with Norville Wilder Supply Company.
So I did, and to make a long story short, I went to work for him in the Houston office.
And I was helping sell pumping units and designing for sale little reciprocating skid mounted gasoline engine driven pumps for gathering systems for pipelines and so forth.
So I went to work for Norval Wilder.
And while I was working for them there in Houston after about eight or nine months, I had a lot of good friends in the Shell.

And I was approached one day and they said, look, we know you're an engineer and we're trying to put together a task force here, a super duper task force to evaluate oil properties because Shell is going to expand its production through acquisition.
And would you be interested?
I said, well, I don't know.
I haven't been working here for a while or very long.
I've got a good job and I like it.
I just got married.
And they said, well, this is really going to be an opportunity.
They said, we're bringing a world-renowned geologist over from The Hague that will teach this group the techniques and so forth.
The more they talked about it, the more exotic it sounded.
So I took the job and went to work there in the top floor of the Shell Building in Houston.

About eight or ten engineers and they brought this little Swiss, Dr. Wilhelm from The Hague, that he was absolutely a genius and about his theories on subsurface analysis to analyze existing oil fields and structures as to
how much oil was going to be recovered from them and what the value was and what the future value would be.

Shell had devised certain guidelines of they wouldn't look at a property unless it would show an average payout of such and such and the average annual profit would be at least 22% or something like that.

So for about three months, we just kind of went and had a super-duper postgraduate course in subsurface analysis and in Schlumberger law of interpretation and correlation and some other exotic theories.
And then, meanwhile, the Land Department of Shell was getting all these pieces of
And Shell and the Land Department would submit this lease down to this task group for our recommendations.
And then Wilhelm would parcel it out to us.
And we'd analyze it and write a report on what our analysis was.
And based on that, Shell would either buy or not buy the properties.
And it just functioned beautifully.
One of the guys that was there was a famous West Point
graduate and all-American football player, Johnny Merle, who was cashiered out of the Army because of an alleged rape of a socialite at Fort San Houston in San Antonio.
And he was, he was kind of a, he wasn't a good guy.
He was kind of a rogue, but a very, very brilliant guy and had
been out of the service about three years and had worked for Shell.
And it was really brilliant.
And he later became the head of McNaughton and Degalia Consulting Outfit in Dallas, which is the most famous oil consulting firm in the world.
Johnny Merle was, he's, I think he's, no, he's not still the head of it.
There's another ex-Aggie the head of it.
But Johnny Merle was in this group there, this evaluation group.
And of course I was intrigued by knowing him and learning about all his days at West Point when he was an all-American halfback.
But he was really a rogue.
Were you working for Shell then?
I worked for Shell then, yeah.
Well, this thing functioned like a house of fire for about a year.
And then Norval Wilder was going to expand and go into West Texas and build some stores.
And they contacted me and said, look, you want to come back to work for us?
And we want you to go out to Midland and be our division manager and build a couple of stores in some of the new fields.
And this more or less gave me a blank check.
So I said, yeah, I will.
I said, I've learned about all I can learn here in this hotshot group.
And it was really fascinating.
Every day was just like a joy to go to work because there's something new every day.
And I got a lot of personal satisfaction out of it.
So I went back out to West Texas and set myself up in Midland and built a store in Monahans for Norwood Wilder, which is west of Midland, and worked there.
got an interest in an airplane, a little yellow bomber.
We call it the yellow peril, a little Piper Cub.
Five of us formed a flying club and bought it.
One of them was a former Navy carrier pilot, and he polished everybody's flying skills up on it.
And so this was late in 1940.
and we went happily along there for six or seven months.
And lo and behold, one day I landed the plane at Midland, at the Midland Airport.
It was a small army detachment for refueling and for weather gathering purposes.
There was a couple of sergeants, a couple of master sergeants, and five or six other enlisted men.
the planes from Randolph and Kelly would come through on cross country and they'd stop there for refueling before they went on to El Paso.
And they ran a little weather station too.
And I'd been up to Yoakum County in the Piper Cub and we had these Air Force guys, Air Corps guys kind of looking after our plane and we for that we
This Navy pilot taught a couple of them to fly.
And they'd polish our plane up, and they'd give us safety wire.
Of course, they had a little spare part, and they'd give us spark plugs.
God knows how much free Army Air Corps stuff we got from them.
Well, anyway, I was taxiing.
I'd been up to Yoakum County and was taxiing up to our little hangar.
The sergeant was running across the field waving a yellow piece of paper.
He said, I hadn't even cut the switch on the plane yet.
He hollered, he said, I didn't know you were a reserve officer.
I said, yeah.
So I cut the switch and I said, what the hell's cutting?
He said, I got a Twix for you over our weather network from Washington.
I said, well, who's it signed by?
He said, well, it's signed by somebody named Gregory.
He said...
I said, who is that?
He said, I don't know, but he must be a high ranking guy.
He wouldn't be signing messages.
So asking me would I come on duty for one year to help in the activation and design of military pipeline companies.
Now at this time, had you been going to any reserve meetings?
I hadn't been going to any meetings, but I had gone to camp.
I'd gone to camp every year since I graduated.
So a two-week camp in the summer?
Yeah, a two-week camp.
And what rank were you by then?
I was first lieutenant.
First lieutenant, sure was.
First lieutenant in the Field Artillery Reserve and my last camp had been at
Fort D.A.
Russell in Marfa, Texas.
It was a 105 millimeter howitzer outfit down there that I was assigned to.
Artillery outfit, because I was artillery, field artillery reserve.
And it turns out that Gregory was a quartermaster general in Washington.
And asking me would I come on duty for one year to help design and buy the equipment and

for this military pipeline company, which was a new concept of a military organization to lay pipelines so that we could push forward by pipeline diesel fuel and gasoline for tanks and vehicles and make it easier to supply and support armored columns and so forth.
And this was a quick laying, a Victaulic couple pipeline you lay right on top of the ground.
You lay it real fast.
So it... Is it pretty lightweight pipe?
Not real lightweight.
No, it's steel pipe.
It's not aluminum, it's steel pipe.
No, it weighs, the four inch I guess, it weighs about
Mmm, three pounds per foot.
Well anyway... And so it was considered the idea, what was the idea behind it?
Could you tell me a little bit about that?
Why did they want to do that instead of have, have gasoline trucks?
Because this was much better than having gasoline trucks.
It would give you a, a logistic line of support
more dependable than a vehicle, which uses fuel as well.
And it's most efficient.
It's the most efficient way to move liquid products of anything is by pipeline.
And so I was really, I was just shocked.
Hell, I just built a house in Midland, my wife is pregnant.
And I had a good job and of course the war was coming, you could see that.
This was in December 1940.
Late December 1940.
I guess it was around Christmas or may have been between Christmas and New Year's because I remember it was cold out there in West Texas then.
And I
The sergeant said, you can send an answerer back over the net.
He said, I can put it on the teletype for you.
I said, well, hell, I can't answer it today.
I've got to think about this.
I've got to talk to my company.
So we pondered about it.
And I was sure that we were going to be involved in the war, because we were already, you know, we had to draft.
And we were already mobilizing and already in Lend-Lease.
So I talked to my Lip Norville, whose office was here in Fort Worth, and told him what the telegram that I've got.
Asked me to come on duty for a year.
He said, well, why don't you go ahead?
And he said, we'll pay the difference between your salary and first lieutenant.
We'll.
Really?
Yeah.
And we'll pay.
Gee whiz.
How nice.
We'll pay in the social security for you.
We'll pay into Social Security for you.
And he said, I presume they'll pay your travel and move your wife up to Washington, won't they?
I said, well, I guess they will.
I know they'll pay my travel.
He said, well, if they won't pay for Sue going up there, we'll pay for her going up there.
And they were real nice about it.
No kidding.
So about a week or 10 days later, I went out to the airport and I said, let's send an answer to this message.
So I did and told them I would.
And so early in January, I got back a reply from ordering me to go to the hospital in El Paso, William Beaumont General Hospital, for a final type physical, which I did.
in which I passed and they sent it on to Horsman.
Then about three weeks after that I flew the Piper Cub out there to El Paso.
Bucked headwinds all the way, took about four hours to fly that, no about three hours to fly that 300 odd miles to El Paso.
In about three weeks, two or three weeks after that I got orders.
directing me to report to Washington on the 8th of March.
So that started off.
I drove up there and reported.
My wife came on up in about two weeks.
Our son was born in May.
There were about six other
five, five other patrols of engineers they had brought on duty.
And we, we all had, we all had had some experience with pipeline gathering systems and pumps, so everybody was pretty well zeroed in on it.
And we all had about the same idea as, oh hell, it didn't take us but about six weeks.
We, we had worked out a table of equipment
And what we felt would be that the capabilities of an organization of this size made up a list of materials which was approved very quickly to buy six sets of it.
And in about four months time, the stuff started rolling in to Fort Belvoir, Virginia, right there.
Near Washington.
Well, after we got this thing launched,
Well, I then had nothing further to do with the Military Pipeline Company.
I later, in later life, later service, had a lot to do with it in Japan after the war.
But during World War II then,
I hadn't gotten along so well there in the staff capacity that Christ, they wouldn't let me go out to Belvoir to help run the thing after we had given birth to it.
There's another guy and I that they kept back there, and we were kept in planning and other logistic assignments.
Well, after these four months, were you eager to get back to the civilian job then?
Well I was on duty for a year see and I was ordered to duty for a year and lo and behold in December the 7th Pearl Harbor came and that had ended the year.
I was in for the duration then.
Yes I was anxious but they said well no can't let you off now.
You can get off when your year is up but before that
So that's how it all started.
And I guess if I had it to do over, I don't believe I would change the scenario any, really.
Even after the war was over and I came back to civilian life, I had an opportunity to go to work for
the Coleman Company that makes the lanterns and everything.
I got very well acquainted with Sheldon Coleman.
He's the chairman of the Coleman Company and he's the son of the old man Coleman whom I also met early in the war.
I got really acquainted with those guys I guess through some of the
extra effort in activities I engaged in, which I'm sure didn't hurt my career at all.

But early in the war, about the time we were, no, early, long before we got in the war, when we were working on this military pipeline concept, I read some of these reports of the British fighting in Libya, and British armoured, and how they were moving their fuel,
One thing that always intrigued me was they were always talking about making tea or heating bully beef and everything and they had really no little stove to do it with.
And they would hollow out a little hole in the sand and kind of coop it up and put a little hole and pour some petrol in there and light it and then hold a pan or a container over it while it burned.
to heat water to make tea or to heat a mess kit that had bully beef in it and stew.
Whereas if they had a little stove, well it would have been a neat little thing.
So I got the idea one day and I mentioned it to one of the research people there in the Quartermaster General's office.
I said why don't we, why don't we build a, why don't we design a
a little stove that armored units or that people in vehicles would have and they could cook a meal in the field.
Even heat up combat rations, sea rations, or at least heat water to shave with or coffee.
And this guy that I talked to, I forget who he was,
He said, we've got a stove.
He said, the mountain troops, and we had a few mountain troops.
He said, they've got a little stove to melt the wax for skis, to melt ski wax, to put on skis.
And I said, well, where is one of them?
Have you seen one?
He said, yeah.
So he got one and showed it to me.
And I said, well, hell, we could start with this thing.
It was made by Coleman.
So.
What did it look like?

It was a little small square container and had a little top and a little burner unit very similar to gasoline lantern and you pumped air into this little fount where the gasoline was and you then got a little pressurized vapor and you turned the burner on and lit it.
So,

I said, we could really make something here if we take this thing and design a container to carry it and let this container, this carrying case, be the container also to heat water in and stuff like that.
A double purpose thing.
So he said, well, this Coleman representative comes around here occasionally.
I said, well, who is he?
So he looked it up, and I called him up.
I said, look, we've got a wild idea here.
And I said, maybe you can do something.
Maybe we can work something up.
I had no charter to do anything like this.
And I went to one of the senior officers in the plans or operations branch, and I told him, he said, well, we have no requirement for anything like that.
And I said, well, I know we don't, but someday we might have a requirement, or maybe we ought to develop a requirement for it.
So the Coleman guy came, and I told him what my idea was, and we discussed it.
And he said, well, let us play around with it a little bit.
So he apparently passed the information on out to Wichita, to their home office.
Two, three days, a young Sheldon Coleman called me.
The old man was still alive then and running the company.
And he said, we're intrigued by your idea here of a little military one-burner stove.

And we believe that we can do something with it and make a container, a carrying case out of aluminum that would serve as a container and also serve as something that you could heat water in, particularly the top of it, because the bottom might get the smell of gasoline a little bit with the fount sitting on it.
And I said, well, the brass around here says we don't have a requirement for it, but maybe we would if people knew that we had such a thing.
So he said, well, I'm coming to Washington in two or three weeks, and we'll bring a hand-fabricated model in.
So they did.
And they showed it to me first.
So I got a hold of this colonel and I told him what we had and I said, would you like for us to bring it up there and let me show it to you and Mr. Coleman show it to you?
He said, yeah, come ahead.
So we did.
He was intrigued by it and of course he said, we still don't, you know, we don't have a requirement for anything like this.
So he took it into his boss, we all traipsed into his office
And he was intrigued with it.
This last guy was named Charlie Hoss, and he was a colonel.
But we just passed the time of day, and they said, well, if we think we can do something with this or there is a great need for it, well, we'll be back in touch with you, telling Sheldon Coleman.
So about three weeks after that, Sheldon left and he left me the little hand-fabricated thing.
I put it in my desk.
I took it and I tried it out.
It worked fine.
But, you know, we were busy on a lot of other things.
I think we were, I forget what the hottest projects were then, but Pearl Harbor had already happened then and we were working on
We were already working on the G4 annex for the landings in North Africa, for the North African invasion.
And a little bit later, took a couple of weeks after that, Colonel Haas came around and he said, say that stove that Mr. Coleman had in here.
He says, was that our idea or his idea?
I said, well, really it was our basic idea and we told them.
They've patterned our idea into some flesh and bones.
And he said, you know, he said, I think we can squeeze a little money and we might buy a few of them.
And I said, well, that's fine.
He says, how many do you suppose we could buy for $10,000 if I could get that much off of one of these other projects?
And I said, I don't know, but I'll sure find out quick.
So I called Sheldon out in Wichita and I said, how many of those stoves can you buy, can we buy for $10,000?
